Message.Title: I want to talk about how I arrived at my investing strategy for Apple. I am going to look at the 2 extreme ways you cam invest in Apple, and then a compromise method that lies in between these 2 extremes.
Message.Msg: The first method is to be invested 100% in Apple all the time. You ride through all the sell offs and suffer the 20-25% draw downs that eventually come. For a lot of people, it is really difficult not to panic during a 25% sell off. Very few people can manage this. If you are in options, that 25% sell off can be magnified to a 50-70% draw down which is both impossible to handle and definitely not recommended. When Apple goes parabolic you never sell. This too can be very difficult to resist. Let’s say Apple goes up on average 40% a year. That will be your return unless you are in options. We already discovered why being 100% in options is not practical, so rule that idea out. Being 100% invested is nearly impossible for the average human being and exposes you to some really scary sell offs.

Message.Title: The opposite method
Message.Msg: The completely opposite way to invest in Apple is to approach it like a day trader. You are long Apple, neutral and in cash, or short Apple. Day trading or swing trading Apple 100% requires a high skill level. That skill level will require about 5 years of full time trading to break even and another 5 years before you are making a good living. That’s like 10 years of college with losses to boot. Once you are successful your returns will provide you a good living but it is rare to find a rich day trader or short term swing trader. There are a few, but trust me, they are rare.

Message.Title: The compromise
Message.Msg: My method is a system that falls in between these two extremes and tries to pick up on the benefits of both while avoiding the negatives of both. It also deals with the human emotions of greed and fear that really play havoc with an investor’s decisions. Basically I stay fully invested with 50% of my portfolio all the time. I ride through all the sell offs and enjoy all the parabolic runs. With only 50% invested, I can weather the draw downs without the extreme pressure to sell everything. It allows me to make those fabulous returns when Apple makes those exciting parabolic runs. The other 50% is only invested in those one or two times a quarter when Apple sells off hard and I go in and get fully invested with that 50%. I use the last 2 quarters PE range to help guide me when Apple is nearing that point. Right now that average low PE ratio is around 13. I also closely monitor the SPY to help me in that determination. I sell off 50% when Apple runs up into earnings. I have learned it is best to take this 50% off before earnings. Riding through earnings with 100% invested can be painful on those 20% of the time when Apple gaps down.

Message.Title: Trading Leaps with Short Calls
Message.Msg: Now, on to high delta LEAPS. The purpose of very deep in the money LEAP options is to treat them as stock replacement. For example, the January 2014 360 call option is very high delta, basically following the underlying stock dollar for dollar. If AAPL goes up $1, these call options go up $1, same if AAPL goes down $1. This aspect is critically important. Using LEAPs, we are able to leverage our money significantly.There are many, many ways to play covered calls with LEAPS, and I’m just outlining one. You can play the monthlies, you can day trade (i.e. write ATM calls, then buy back for profit on an intraday dip, wait for it to run up and do it again), you can even be very aggressive and sell ATM or ITM short calls if you are convinced AAPL has peaked and is sure to drop before expiration.

Message.Title: AT&T Gives Iphones Added Speed Using Bandwidth
Message.Msg: Iphone is a Bandwidth hog and that means big dollars for AT&T. The U.S. is far behind the international market for smartphones, speeds are much higher outside the U.S.. There are security issues on processor chips made outside the U.S., Apple's processor chips are made in the U.S. and that gives them an edge here in the U.S.. Quad Core vs Dual Core chips: Quad Core is much faster but is controlled by the software, software can be written to use all 4 cores but in most cases they use only 2 of those cores. Phones outside the U.S. using Quad Core chips are forced to use the CDMA chips here in the U.S.. INTEL's Quad Core processors are twice as fast as their Dual Core chips found in desk top and lap top computers. Games demand the most from processor chips and many games today will turn on all 4 cores but games must think about speed first before excess power drain. Smartphones makers must do both, they must think about the power drain of the battery and the speed to run an application, Apple does a fine job with both. Technology is moving fast in the world of processor chips, the race is on for a smaller, faster chip that uses far less power, soon we will see chips that will make smartphone batteries last for days and not hours.

Message.Title: Mortgage-Bond Selling Shows Anxieties Despite Fed Support WSJ BUBBLE BURST FAST APPROACHING
Message.Msg: By Al Yoon Two weeks ago, the Federal Reserve‘s brash new quantitative easing program left its primary target, the $5 trillion market for mortgage-backed securities, brimming with enthusiasm. But the optimism–following some estimates for nearly $1 trillion of MBS purchases over an open-ended period–has bowed to new anxieties that promise to make what seemed an obvious trade a rocky ride. After posting its biggest rally in more than four years directly following the QE announcement, the market since Tuesday has given back a chunk of those gains as money managers unwound trades put on months ago in anticipation of the Fed’s move. To be bullish makes sense with such a big buyer showing up each trading day. On Thursday, the Fed reported a net $20.1 billion in purchases for the past week, signaling a monthly pace that may exceed the $65 billion to $70 billion estimated by analysts after the Fed announced its program on Sept. 13.

Message.Title: Apple iPad Mini release date moves closer with new production rumours
Message.Msg: Apple's much-rumoured iPad Mini looks set for an imminent release with latest reports suggesting the tablet has already entered mass production. While many tech fans were disappointed by the lack of iPad Mini news at Apple's September 12 iPhone 5 unveiling, they might not have to wait too much longer for the new device. The iPad Mini is expected to arrive next month, with an Apple launch event pencilled in for October 10. And reports which surfaced today appear to support the proposed date, claiming mass production of the under wraps Mini is already underway. The initial article, first published in Taiwan's Economic Daily News and later picked up by a plethora of tech sites, reports that the main bulk of the device's production will be done by Chinese firm Pegatron. The firm has reportedly secured between 50 to 60 per cent of production orders from Apple, spelling the end of rival assemblers Foxconn's monopoly on iPad production. Analysts speculate a 7.85in product featuring a thinner screen frame to allow a bigger display area as well as a resolution similar to that of the iPad 2. Apple will be confident of building on the success of its recent iPhone 5 launch which attracted a record breaking 2million pre-orders in just 24 hours.

Message.Title: Tomorrow aapl tests 662 then bounce back to
Ipad mini roumors
Message.Msg: Reliable Apple news source MacRumors has posted a new report, quoting Macotakara, claiming to show the unannounced Apple iPad Mini, the rumored 7.85-inch tablet computer that will run the latest version of Apple’s mobile operating system, iOS 6. The reports say the mockup “has confirmed” that Apple’s iPad Mini will ship with the new lightning port, the company’s new charging and syncing port that replaced the old 30-pin dock connector. The iPhone 5 is the first to use the lightning port. Also, the mockup is suggesting that the iPad Mini’s headphone jack will remain on the top of the device, unlike the iPhone 5 that features the jack below the phone, near the built-in speakers and charging port. According to rumors, Apple will start shipping the iPad Mini before Thanksgiving, and with a “cheaper” price tag, the device is said to compete with Google’s popular Nexus 7 Android tablet, Amazon’s Kindle Fire HD and the new Barnes and Noble Nook HD tablet computers. Apple’s iPad 2 is currently the cheapest iPad in the market, so it is highly possible that the iPad Mini will sport the cheapest price tag ever to lure more customers.

Message.Title: MUST READ FOR ALL HERE:Hey Apple: Check Out this Rumor
Message.Msg: Hey Apple: Check Out this Rumor By Meghan Foley | More Articles September 30, 2012 If rumors are true, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is not the only tablet manufacturer releasing a new device before the holiday season. According to a report in the electronics publication Digitimes, Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) plans to offer Apple’s reported new iPad mini some competition in the form of a cheaper, thinner version of the Nexus 7. Already one of the most popular 7-inch tablets on the market, the Nexus 7 has gained market share over both Apple and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) since its release in mid-July. According to data compiled by analytics firm Chitika, the Google Nexus accounts for 68.5 percent of tablet Web traffic in the United States and Canada. Apple has been a huge winning stock pick for Wall St. Cheat Sheet Newsletter subscribers. Don’t waste another minute — click here and get more of our CHEAT SHEET stock picks now. Reportedly, two models will be released by Google; one priced at $99 and the other at $199. The new models will be aimed directly at competing with Apple’s rumored $300 7.85-inch iPad mini. But if Google’s new tablets do carry the lower price tag, some tradeoffs, like less storage, will have to be made to get to the $99 price point. Otherwise, Google could accept a loss on the tablet in hopes that customers would make up for lost revenue through sales from Google Play, the company’s app store which currently lags between that Amazon, Apple, and Barnes & Noble (NYSE:BKS). Asustek, the company which manufactured the current Nexus 7, has denied the rumor.

Message.Title: Five Reasons Apple Should Split Its Stock and Four Reasons Not To
Message.Msg: Five Reasons Apple Should Split Its Stock and Four Reasons @ Forbes I think this article @ Forbes is interesting. It pretty is saying apple may still be undervalued. It is just the high stock price to prevent it to move forward. 'Despite Apple’s 70% price appreciation over the last year, its stock remains undervalued. Apple has performed as one of the strongest and most consistent growth stocks over the past decade, yet is penalized by trading at a Price Earnings to Growth Ratio of less than one. According to Jim Cramer, the metric for a growth stock is to pay up to 2 times Price Earnings to Growth and the metric for value stocks, those that are simply performing well at steady state, is a Price Earnings to Growth of 1 times. Apple trades below this. One reason: The stock needs to split, five to one, in order to bring more investors into the stock. Moreover, a stock split by Apple would be synonymous with its product strategy as well: Establish demand at the high-end then make it attainable for everyone. There are five advantages for Apple to do a five-to-one stock split: The Math: the stock doesn’t become cheaper, it just becomes affordable. Expectations for Apple stock price are now around $1,000 per share within a couple years. Although most investors, professional and retail, can understand intellectually that a $1,000 stock earning $100 per share is mathematically the same as 20 $50 stocks earning $5 per share. And investors also understand that a $50 stock earning $5 per share and growing at 20% per year is more attractive than a $50 stock earning $5 per share but growing at 5% per year. The first Price-to-Earnings ratio in this example is 10.0x with a growth rate of 20% versus a growth rate of 5%, or a PEG of 0.5x versus a PEG of 2.0x. Again investors prefer the theoretical $50 stock with $5 earnings at 20% growth, because it is cheaper. They “buy” more growth for the same P/E. This is why Apple’s current PEG (FY13, excluding cash) of 0.6x is very attractive, but many investors can’t get over the size of the current price of $667. By splitting the stock five-to-one, each new share is $133.40; and it now becomes more psychologically affordable to investors. After all, investors want more than one share of stock for their $667, even though that $667 will produce the same total earnings. A Five-to-One stock split puts Apple stock at $133, still a premium price point, but not unattainable…like its products. Think of Apple’s product strategy in terms of computers and iPods. Both competed in commoditized markets (PCs and MP3 players) where the basis of competition was price. In both cases, Apple’s products remained priced at price-points that were higher than competing brands and Apple still was able to create buzz and desire for their products at higher points. Then, in both cases, Apple brought the products to a larger audience by introducing “lighter” versions, like the white MacBook, or the iPod Shuffle. While the functionality, size, memory were smaller than their MacBookPro or iPod Classic brethren, they opened up the market to more people who coveted the products but couldn’t afford the original price points. By opening up the addressable audience, Apple has become a market leader in MP3 players world wide and has been able to grow its computer business at a pace 7.5 times the industry average. Now, think of Apple’s stock. It remains at a very high price point, and is only attainable to institutional investors, high net worth investors and some retail investors who can get over the previous argument. By splitting the stock 5 to 1, the stock price becomes attainable to a larger audience. More investors mean a wider investor base. In Why is Apple’s P/E so Low? and the same Part 2, I make the case that Apple’s current institutional investor base may be “maxed” out on how much stock they can hold. Traditional money managers, like State Street, may be limited in their charter of how much of one stock they can hold. For example, a fund may be limited 3-5% of one stock for diversification. Once they fill their position, they can’t buy more; and if the stock appreciates, it would exceed its limited proportion of the fund and the fund managers would have to sell. So, in this world, perversely, a well-chosen investment may have to be sold out of a fund, not because its prospects have diminished but because it has performed too well. This puts an artificial ceiling of how much demand can exist by traditional fund managers for Apple stock and an mechanism by which the stock remains “stuck” in a particular range. A wider investor base unlocks value in the stock. One benefit of Apple’s announcement in March to pay dividends was to increase the potential audience of fund managers who could buy Apple for their portfolios. If you look at the trading chart of Apple before it announced the dividend, it appeared stuck in the range of roughly $330-$415; after the announcement, the stock popped up into a new range of $530-$640. The wider the audience and greater demand for Apple stock, the closer the stock can come to parity with its PEG ratio. A stock split will make the stock more attractive to retail investors who tend to hold stocks, rather than trade around them. Should Apple split its stock to become more “affordable,” it opens up this investor base as well as creates a positive emotional benefit to the stock. Stock splits are associated with growth companies whose earnings are expected to continue to expand. Apple’s earnings continue to grow and accelerate. For the past three fiscal years, Apple’s EPS have grown 34%, 67% and 83%. Current estimates peg Apple’s earnings at a 69% growth over last year. Note, Apple’s market capitalization is currently $625B. Previously only oil companies, propelled by oil prices, and Cisco and Microsoft had market capitalizations in excess of $500B. Interestingly, Cisco and Microsoft achieved their high market caps due to high P/Es. Cisco’s P/E increased from 68x in October 1998 to over 200x in April 2000. Microsoft’s P/E ranged from 56x to 81x in the same period. On the same basis, Apple’s is currently 16x. It has achieved its large market capitalization in spite of its P/E. Lastly, a stock split would make its product fans happy. Many Apple product owners feel priced out of investing in the stock, for the above reasons. Apple should support the very customers that make them successful and let their customers benefit from Apple’s increased sales through stock ownership. There are four arguments against Apple doing a stock split: High stock prices keep out frivolous investors, argues Berkshire Hathaway. Berkshire Hathaway is a different type of stock, more like fund of value investments than a single company stock. Buffet wants his investors in for the long haul because he is often investing significant amounts in turnaround or bottom-of-the-cycle companies. Often these investments are difficult for his investors to understand. He needs investors to give him a longer runway to prove out his investment thesis. Apple is not this situation at all: retail investors can touch, feel and evaluate the product and its prospects. It is more difficult to beat earnings after a stock split. This is an argument for a company that has difficulty managing their earnings. So, for example, if a company earns $1.00 per share before a five-for-one stock split, those earnings now become $0.20. If it “beats” its earnings forecast by $0.05 that translates into $1.05 before the split and $0.21, only beating by one penny – far less glamorous and noteworthy. Again, it doesn’t really apply in Apple’s case. Apple has beat earnings estimates in nine of the last eleven reporting periods, six of those by $1.00 or more. Even with a five-for-one stock spilt, Apple would be beating by $0.20 or more: a very newsworthy beat with the split." This is just a part of it. Please search the article and read the full article. Please note all the credential should go to the author.

Message.Title: Steve Wozniak... another investor fleeing Obama's America
Message.Msg: One of the hallmarks of the Obama era is "capital flight". 6 years have passed since Harry Ried and Nancy Pelosi took over congress and resurrected the term "dead on arrival" to characterize Bush's last 2 years of proposals to congress... but the magnitude of wealthy americans fleeing the U.S. didn't seriously spike until Obama took office and Reid secured a filibuster-proof senate for a year... long enough to pass Obama's top priorities. Another of the higher-profile ex-patriations was Edwardo Saverin... the co-founder of facebook, who took his facebook IPO money ($3 billion) and fled to Singapore, a low-tax, supply-side economy with solid growth and low un-employment (Mr. Obama hates the Singapore model and has embraced the european model). So, while Obama presides over record, fiscal stimulus ($1.2 Trillion deficits) and Bernanke conducts un-precedented monetary stimulus (massive creation of money... eg: the "printing press" solution)... ... our country still has high-unemployment, no growth, and massive deficits. Why? Because no-one with "investment capital" will invest in the U.S. as long as Obama threatens them every day with endless, class-warfare rhetoric. "Capital deployment" has essentially "seized up" in America... and capital deployment is the mothers milk of new business and new american jobs. Instead, investment capital is fleeing... and in a private moment, I'm sure Mr. Wozniak would tell you why.
